title: 113_hr4763
content: The Act may be cited as the "Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act" and addresses unfair practices in import trade. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act amends Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to include substantial investment in licensing activities that lead to the development of articles incorporating intellectual property rights. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act amends Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to include restrictions on relying on licensee activities for complaints, and requires a preliminary investigation before initiating a Commission investigation based on certain activities. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act amends Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to include restrictions on relying on licensee activities for complaints. A preliminary investigation is required before initiating a Commission investigation based on certain activities. The preliminary investigation determines the likelihood of an industry existing or being established in the United States within 45 days of filing the complaint. The complainant's case is limited to the assertions and evidence in the complaint, while additional facts, evidence, and arguments can be provided by named respondents and the public. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act amends Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to include restrictions on initiating a Commission investigation without evidence of an industry in the United States. The Commission can terminate investigations based on private party agreements or consent orders. The Trade Protection Not Troll Protection Act amends Section 337 of the Tariff Act of 1930 to include restrictions on initiating a Commission investigation without evidence of an industry in the United States. The Commission can terminate investigations based on public interest considerations, including the impact on public health, competitive conditions, domestic production, and market demand for protected articles. Amendments include considerations of equitable defenses and principles in exclusion decisions for public interest, including public health and welfare.
